'''William Dudley "Big Bill" Haywood''' ([[February 4]], [[1869]]–[[May 18]], [[1928]]) was a prominent figure in [[United States|American]] radical [[labor union|unionism]]. As a leader in the [[Western Federation of Miners]] (WFM) and later as a founding member of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW), he was involved in several high-profile labor disputes and was often the target of prosecution.
â
Haywood began working in the [[Mining|mines]] at age nine, the same year he lost his right eye in a widdling accident. After brief stints as a [[cowboy]] and a [[homesteader]], he returned to mining and rose through the ranks of the union to become a member of the WFM national union's General Executive Board in [[1900]], and editor of the union's magazine, then serving as secretary-treasurer in [[1901]].
+
==The Formative Years==
â
In [[1901]], [[class warfare]] erupted in the mines of [[Colorado]] that took the lives of 33 union and non-union workers. The WFM initiated a series of strikes to combat the brutal working conditions and starvation wages. The defeat of these strikes led to Haywood's belief in "One Big Union" organized along industrial lines to bring broader [[working class]] support for labour struggles.
+
Haywood was born in 1869 in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. His father, a [[Pony Express]] rider, died of pnemonia when Haywood was three years old (Linder 1998). At age nine, he injured his right eye while [[whittle|whittling]], permanantly blinding it.{{ref|photos}} Also at age nine, he began working in the [[Mining|mines]]. After brief stints as a [[cowboy]] and a [[homesteader]], he returned to mining.{{fact}} High-profile events such as the [[Haymarket Riot]] in 1886 and the [[Pullman Strike]] in 1894 fostered Haywood's interest in the labor movement (Linder 1998).
â
Late in [[1904]], Haywood along with over 30 other prominent labour radicals, met in Chicago to lay down plans for a new revolutionary union. A manifesto was written and sent around the country. Unionists who agreed with the manifesto were invited to attend a convention to found the new union which was to become the [[Industrial Workers of the World]].
+
==Experience in the WFM==
â
At 10 A.M. on June 27, [[1905]], Haywood addressed the crowd assembled at Brand's Hall in [[Chicago]] who had gathered to the Industrial Workers of the World founding convention. In the audience were nearly 200 delegates from organizations all over the country representing [[socialists]], [[anarchists]], [[miners]], [[industrial unionists]] and rebel workers.
+
In 1896, [[Ed Boyce]], president of the [[Western Federation of Miners]], spoke at the [[Idaho]] silver mine where Haywood was working (Linder 1998). Inspired by his speech, Haywood signed up as a WFM member, thus formally beginning his involvement in America's labor movement.
â
:"Fellow Workers, this is the Continental Congress of the Working Class. We are here to confederate the workers of this country into a working-class movement in possession of the economic powers, the means of life, in control of the machinery of production and distribution without regard to [[capitalist]] masters."
    +
Haywood immediately became active in the WFM, and by 1900 he had become a member of the national union's General Executive Board. In 1902, he assumed co-leadership of the WFM with [[Charles Moyer]]. That year, the WFM became involved in the [[Colorodo Labor Wars]], a struggle that latest for several years and took the lives of 33 union and non-union workers(Linder 1998). The WFM initiated a series of strikes to combat the brutal working conditions and starvation wages. The defeat of these strikes led to Haywood's belief in "One Big Union" organized along industrial lines to bring broader [[working class]] support for labour struggles.{{fact}}
  +   +
==Foundation of the IWW==
  +   +
Late in [[1904]], Haywood along with over 30 other prominent labour radicals, met in Chicago to lay down plans for a new revolutionary union.{{fact}} A manifesto was written and sent around the country. Unionists who agreed with the manifesto were invited to attend a convention to found the new union which was to become the [[Industrial Workers of the World]].
  +   +
At 10 A.M. on June 27, [[1905]], Haywood addressed the crowd assembled at Brand's Hall in [[Chicago]] who had gathered to the Industrial Workers of the World founding convention (Zinn 2001:329). In the audience were two hundred delegates from organizations all over the country representing [[socialists]], [[anarchists]], miners, [[industrial unionists]] and rebel workers. Haywood began the convention with the following speech (Zinn 2001:329-330):
  +   +
:''Fellow Workers, this is the Continental Congress of the working-class. We are here to confederate the workers of this country into a working-class movement that shall have for its purpose the emancipation of the working-class from the slave bondage of capitalism. The aims and objects of this organization shall be to put the working-class in possession of the economic power, the means of life, in control of the machinery of production and distribution, without regard to capitalist masters.''
  +   +
Other speakers at the convention included [[Eugene Debs]], leader of the Socialist Party, and [[Mary Jones|Mother Mary Jones]], an organizer for the [[United Mine Workers of America]] (Zinn 2001:330). After it's foundation, the IWW would become aggressivly involved in the labor movement.
  +   +
==Murder Trial==
  +
<!-- THIS SECTION NEEDS TO BE EXPANDED-->
Haywood was put on trial in May [[1907]] for the assassination of [[Frank Steunenberg]], governor of [[Idaho]] after being implicated by [[Harry Orchard]]. He had been kidnapped in Denver by Pinkerton Detective Agency operatives with the connivance of the Governors of both Colorado and Idaho, and was smuggled back to Idaho for trial. Haywood was defended by [[Clarence Darrow]]; the prosecutor was William Borah, afterward Senator from Idaho. He was acquitted.
Haywood was put on trial in May [[1907]] for the assassination of [[Frank Steunenberg]], governor of [[Idaho]] after being implicated by [[Harry Orchard]]. He had been kidnapped in Denver by Pinkerton Detective Agency operatives with the connivance of the Governors of both Colorado and Idaho, and was smuggled back to Idaho for trial. Haywood was defended by [[Clarence Darrow]]; the prosecutor was William Borah, afterward Senator from Idaho. He was acquitted.
â
Despite Haywood's involvement in the IWW, which was heavily influenced by [[anarcho-syndicalism]], he was a longtime member of the [[Socialist Party of America]], and often pleaded with workers to vote in elections. In January [[1913]], he was recalled as a member of the Socialist Party National Executive Committee for purportedly advocating violence by a referendum which drew support mainly from [[New York]], [[Massachusetts]], [[Pennsylvania]], and [[Wisconsin]]. His expulsion from the party has been cited as a prime cause of the extremely steep decline in the membership of the Socialist party.
+
==Return to Action==
â
In [[1915]], Haywood became the general secretary-treasurer of the [[Industrial Workers of the World|IWW]]. He led massive textile strikes in [[Massachusetts]] and [[New Jersey]], and assisted in organizing the over three million workers that at one time or another were in the IWW in this era.
+
After the Steunenberg murder trial, Haywood resumed his activity in the labor movement. He was the IWW leader at the [[Lawrence Textile Strike]] in 1912, a bitter struggle that eventually gained many concessions from the textile companies (Zinn 2001:336). Later that year, he encouraged the [[Brotherhood of Timber Workers]] in [[Louisiana]] to invite [[African American]] workers to their convention (though it was illegal) with the following speech (Zinn 2001:337-339):
â
{{wikiquote}}
+
  +
:''You work in the same mills together. Sometimes a black man and a white man chop down the same tree together. You are meeting in a convention now to discuss the conditions under which you labor. Why not be sensible about this and call the Negroes into the Convention? If it is against the law, this is one time when the law should be broken.''
  +   +
Despite Haywood's involvement in the IWW, which was heavily influenced by [[anarcho-syndicalism]], he was a longtime member of the [[Socialist Party of America]], and often pleaded with workers to vote in elections. In January [[1913]], he was recalled as a member of the Socialist Party National Executive Committee for purportedly advocating violence (Zinn 2001:341). His expulsion from the party has been cited as a prime cause of the extremely steep decline in the membership of the Socialist party.{{fact}}
  +   +
==Arrest, Conviction, and Escape==
  +
<!-- THIS SECTION NEEDS TO BE EXPANDED-->
In [[1918]], Haywood was convicted of violating federal [[Espionage Act of 1917|espionage]] and [[Sedition Act of 1918|sedition]] acts by calling a strike during wartime. Sentenced to prison by Judge [[Kenesaw Mountain Landis]], Haywood skipped his [[bond]] while out on appeal and fled to the [[Soviet Union]] where he became an advisor to the [[Bolshevik]] government. Haywood died in [[Moscow]] in 1928. Half of his ashes were buried in [[the Kremlin]] and an urn containing the other half of his ashes was sent to Chicago and buried near a monument to the [[Haymarket Riot|Haymarket anarchists]].
